intro: Pedicularis alaschanica, commonly known as the Alaska beardtongue, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It is a member of the Orobanchaceae family, commonly known as the broomrape family, and is characterized by its erect, hairy stems and showy, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in alpine and subalpine environments, where it thrives in well-drained, rocky soils. Its flowers, which range in color from pink to purple, are adapted for pollination by long-tongued insects such as bees and butterflies. Pedicularis alaschanica is also known for its medicinal uses by indigenous peoples, who have historically used it to treat various ailments.
